Section 306 Pension Not Countable Income
The following types of income are
not
countable income for Section 306 Pension purposes:
income of children
inheritances and gifts of property, as opposed to money
the value of maintenance by a relative, friend, or organization
Welfare and Supplemental Security Income (SSI)
VA pension, compensation, and Dependency and Indemnity Compensation (DIC) benefits
United States Government Life Insurance (USGLI) and National Service Life Insurance (NSLI) proceeds
fire insurance proceeds
proceeds of cashed-in
life insurance policies, and
savings bonds, and
any payment excluded by statute.
Exceptions
:  Unearned income of a child who is the claimant
is
countable when determining that child’s entitlement to VA benefits.
Notes
:
Some savings bonds, such as Series HH U.S. Savings Bonds and some State or municipal bonds, pay interest to the holder without requiring the holder to redeem the bond.  If interest is paid without redemption of the bond, the interest is countable income.
The USGLI and NSLI exclusion applies only when the claimant is the beneficiary under the policy.  If the policy is payable to the Veteran’s estate and the claimant inherits the estate assets, the proceeds are countable.
Other casualty insurance proceeds, other than fire insurance proceeds, are countable.
Part of a child’s income may be countable for a surviving spouse's Survivors Pension if it is paid to the surviving spouse.
References
:  For more information on
a child’s income that may be countable for a surviving spouse’s Survivors Pension, see
38 CFR 3.252(e)(3)
payments specifically excluded by statute, see
M21-1, Part IX, Subpart iii, 1.I.11
the exclusion of cashed-in life insurance or savings bonds, see
Osborn v. Nicholson
,
21 Vet.App. 223 (2007), and
VAOPGCPREC 02-10
, and
specific exclusions for Section 306 Pension countable income, see
38 CFR 3.261
, and
38 CFR 3.262
.
